title: Bass_fishing
added_lines: All black bass are well-known as strong fighters, and are fished recreationally.  Depending upon species and various other factors such as water quality and availability of food, black bass may be found in lakes, reservoirs, ponds, rivers, streams, creeks, even roadside ditches.  Largemouth are known for their overall size and resistance when hooked, favoring short, powerful runs and escape to cover such as submerged logs or weedbeds.<ref name="Waterman, Charles F. 1993">Waterman, Charles F., ''Black Bass & the Fly Rod'', Stackpole Books (1993)</ref>    Largemouth bass are known for their wild jumps while Smallmouth bass are generally accepted as the hardest fighting black bass, pound for pound.  Smallmouth bass tend to jump more and fight aggressively on the surface when hooked, in order to throw the hook. Large mouth bass tend to go after topwater and dark colored plastic worms.  All bass are scent as well as visual predators so care should be taken to ensure no foreign scents, like tobacco, contaminate soft plastics. Largemouth bass anglers tend to catch and release. Bass are usually fileted when taken for the table, and the flesh is white and firm, with a delicate taste when cooked. Largemouth are not generally used for food because the meat has little taste. Largemouth bass offer the best striking ability of all bass and usually give the fisherman the most action.<ref>[http://www.gf.state.az.us/h_f/fish_largemouth_bass.shtml  Arizona Game & Fish Department, ''Bass Fishing in Arizona'']</ref>  However, more bass anglers are adopting "[[catch and release]]" angling where the bass are returned to the water after being hooked and retrieved.

title: Saffron_bun
creator: Jadepearl
added_lines: It is a common mistake to think that the saffron is added to the buns exclusively for colour, whereas in truth it is added as much, if not more, for the taste. Therefore, people who choose to add [[Turmeric]] or other food colouring instead of Saffron will not get the same satisfactory result taste-wise.

title: Andrew_Brenner
creator: CAFESDO
added_lines: While working as County Recorder, Brenner was accused of giving one software company an advantage in a bidding process. The commissioners received complaints, from two companies that did not get Brenner’s recommendation, of illegal bid rigging. The commissioners voted to reject all bids in order to avoid legal action. Because the bids were collectively rejected, the legal and ethical issues were no longer actionable. <ref>http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2010/10/11/Delaware-County-bid-complaints.html</ref>

title: Yoruba_people
creator: Conversion script
added_lines:
Yoruba religion and mythology is a major influence in [[West Africa]], [[Itan]] being the term for the sum total of all [[Yoruba mythology|Yoruba myths]], songs, histories, and other [[Culture|cultural]] components. These mostly originate from the ese (verses) of the Odu Ifa.

Yoruba deities include one creator [[God]] and  some supernatural [[spirit]]s that exist to serve Him. Some of the most prominent divinities are "[[Olorun]]" (God of Heaven), "[[Esu]]" (The Road Opener), "[[Ogun]]" (Spirit of Iron), "[[Obatala]]" (Spirit of justice), "[[Yemoja]]" (Spirit of fertility and salt waters; Mermaid), "[[Oya|Ọya]]" (Guardian of the cemetery/dead), "[[Orunmila]]" (Spirit of divination or fate), "[[Ibeji]]" (Spirit of twins), "Ọsanyin" (Spirit of medicines and healing),  "[[Osun|Ọsun]]" (Spirit of love, protector of children and mothers, ruler of fresh waters), [[Sango]] (Spirit of thunder and lightning), and "Oshosi" (Spirit of the hunt/Protector of those with legal troubles). Some of these deities actually lived amongst the people, often as warriors with fearsome reputations. These reputations often led to them becoming deified in death, with people naturally trying to harness the amazing abilities that they'd displayed. For instance, [[Sango]] (Spirit of thunder and lightning) was said to emit fire from his mouth when he spoke during his life, and was able to initiate and control thunder and lightning.

title: Empathy
creator: Nixdorf
added_lines: In evolutionary psychology, attempts at explaining pro-social behavior often mention the presence of empathy in the individual as a possible variable. Although exact motives behind complex social behaviors are difficult to distinguish, the "ability to put oneself in the shoes of another person and experience events and emotions the way that person experienced them" is the definitive factor for truly altruistic behavior according to Batson's empathy-[[altruism]] hypothesis. If empathy is not felt, social exchange (what's in it for me?) supersedes pure altruism, but if empathy is felt, an individual will help by actions or by word, regardless of whether it is in their self-interest to do so and even if the costs outweigh potential rewards.<ref>{{cite book

title: Batman_Begins
creator: SD6-Agent
added_lines:
At age ten, [[Bruce Wayne]] is playing in his parents' garden with his friend [[Rachel Dawes]] and falls into a cave underground and is attacked by bats. Many years later, Bruce wakes up in a prison in [[Bhutan]] and is approached by [[Henri Ducard]], who witnessed him brutally beat six other inmates who were all more than twice his size. Ducard invites him to join the League of Shadows, led by [[Ra's al Ghul]]. When Bruce first enters the league's home, Ducard suddenly attacks him to test his ability. Ducard notices that Bruce is afraid, but not of him. Bruce then remembers his father helping him get out of the cave he fell into when he was ten. That night, he and his parents went to an opera, but the characters in the show reminded him of the bats who attacked him, so he asks his father to leave out of fear. They leave through a back exit that leads to an alley, where a homeless mugger name Joe Chill shoots both of them and then runs away. Bruce's father tells him not to be afraid, then Bruce watches in horror as both of his parents die.

Years later, Bruce returns to Gotham City from [[Princeton University]] because a hearing is being held to grant Chill early parole in order to testify against [[Carmine Falcone]], Gotham's most powerful and dangerous crime lord. After the judge grants Chill early parole, Bruce attempts to approach him in order to shoot him, but one of Falcone's thugs shoot Chill first. Rachel, who now works in Gotham's District Attorney office, explains to Bruce that Falcone is destroying everything his parents stood for, and that all officials are either too scared to do anything about it or are on Falcone's payroll. Bruce tells her that he was planning to kill Chill, and she slaps him and tells him his father would be ashamed. Bruce then approaches Falcone to tell him that not everyone in Gotham is afraid of him, and Falcone tells him that because of Bruce's wealth and social status, he doesn't understand why everyone fears him. Bruce then runs away to [[Asia]] so he could be somewhere where no one knows who he is and learn about poverty and the criminal mind. He is arrested for assisting in a robbery, which leads up to the events of the beginning.

In present day, Ducard finishes training Bruce, and he tells him that he must complete one last task- to execute a murderer who was being held in custody by the league. Bruce refuses, and is then told by Ra's al Ghul that he needs to kill him in order to lead the league into Gotham to destroy it. To keep them from destroying his home, he burns down their castle, but not before watching Ra's al Ghul die and rescuing Ducard from the burning building. Bruce returns to Gotham, and his butler, [[Alfred Pennyworth]], tells him that the CEO of his father's company, William Earle, had Bruce pronounced dead so he'd be able to run the company the way he wanted and take it public. Bruce then lets Alfred know about his plan to become a symbol to restore hope to the citizens of Gotham by establishing fear in the criminals and corrupt officials of the city. 

Once he returns, Bruce finds out that [[Scarecrow (comics) | Dr. Jonathan Crane]], a phycologist who runs [[Arkham Asylum]], is being paid by Falcone to declare his thugs insane to save them trips to prison, and that the only person who suspects this is Rachel, who Crane wants Falcone to have killed. Bruce gets a battle suit, weaponry, and a war car called the Tumbler from his colleaue at Wayne Enterprises, [[Lucius Fox]]. Bruce, using the alias Batman, stops Falcone from taking in a shipment of illegal drugs and leaves him and his men to be arrested by the Gotham police. Batman then stops Falcone's thugs from killing Rachel before giving her evidence of the wrongdoings of some officials on Falcone's payroll. 

Batman gains the trust of [[James Gordon (comics) | Sgt. Jim Gordon]], who is one of very few honest cops on the police force. Batman tells Gordon that his parter, Sgt. Flask, is working with Falcone. Batman then interrogates Flask to find out about the drugs that were being shipped to Falcone. Crane visits Falcone in prison because he is pleading insane to get out of going to prison. Crane exposes him to a toxin he created that instills fear into its victims. Under the influence of the toxins, Falcone screams in fear, and Crane declares him insane and has him moved to Arkham.

Batman goes after Crane, but is exposed to his toxin and set on fire before being picked up by Alfred. Bruce wakes up two days later because of a cure to the gas created by Fox. Rachel tells Bruce that she is going to confront Crane because he had Falcone moved to Arkham, so he follows her as Batman to protect her from Crane's toxins. He is unable to stop Crane from exposing her to the toxins, however, so he exposes Crane to it himself and asks him who he is working for, to which Crane replies "Ra's al Ghul", which confuses Bruce. Once the police arrive to arrest Batman, Sgt. Gordon helps him and Rachel escape. After a high speed car chase with the police, Batman takes Rachel back to his cave and gives her the antidote created by Fox. 

At Bruce's birthday party that night, he is told by Fox that the toxins created by Crane could be used to expose onto an entire city if used by a microwave emitter like the one that was just stolen from Wayne Enterprises. Later at the party, Bruce is approached by Ducard, who reveals himself to be the real Ra's al Ghul. Ra's tells Bruce that he is going to use Crane's toxins and the microwave emitter to poison Gotham's water supply and destroy the city. He knocks Bruce unconcious and sets fire to his mansion. Alfred gets Bruce into the cave just before the mansion burns down, and once Bruce is about to give up hope on himself, Alfred reminds him of something his father taught him when he was a kid, which motivates him to stop Ra's. 

Ra's has all of the inmates at Arkham released, which causes a huge riot, especially after everyone on the island of Arkham is exposed to the toxins, except for Gordon and Rachel, who were given antidotes by Batman. Just when Gordon thinks he is on his own in stopping the disaster, Batman shows up and tells him what Ra's is planning to do, and that he'll be using the train to get to the water supply. Batman goes after the train while Gordon drives the Tumbler to the tracks to try and destroy the tracks to prevent the train from getting to the water supply. 

After saving Rachel from Crane, who was one of the escaped inmates from Arkham, Bruce reveals his identity to her. He then goes after the train that Ra's is on, and fights him while Gordon is finally able to shoot down the tracks. Bruce separates Ra's' train from the rest of the train and leaves him to die. Ra's accepts his fate, respecting Bruce and the fact that he used everything he taught him against him. 

The next day, Batman is hailed by the public as a hero. Bruce fires Earle and has him replaced by Fox. Rachel approaches Bruce and tells him that she loves him. They kiss, but she tells him that as long as he is Batman, they can never be together, but she will wait for him once the day comes that Gotham no longer needs Batman. Gordon, now a leuitenant, calls Batman to police headquarters using a newly formed bat-signal and tells him that a murderer is on the loose who leaves a Joker playing-card as a calling card. Batman tells him he'll look into it before disappearing into the night.
deleted_lines:
A young [[Bruce Wayne]] falls down a well and is attacked by bats. Bruce then awakens from this nightmare of his past and is revealed to be a prisoner in [[Bhutan]]. He is approached by [[Henri Ducard]], who speaks for [[Ra's al Ghul]], leader of the [[League of Assassins|League of Shadows]], and invites him to train with the elite vigilante group. The narrative returns to Bruce's childhood, to the fateful night he witnessed his parents' murder by a mugger named [[Joe Chill]]. Chill is later arrested and Bruce is taken home and raised by the family [[butler]] [[Alfred Pennyworth]].

Years later, Bruce returns to [[Gotham City]] from [[Princeton University]], intent on killing Chill, whose prison sentence is being suspended in exchange for testifying against crime boss [[Carmine Falcone]]. Before he can act, however, one of Falcone's female assassins posing as a reporter kills Chill. [[Rachel Dawes]], Bruce's childhood friend and now an assistant [[district attorney]], is disgusted with Bruce's intent, telling him his father would be ashamed of him. That night, Bruce confronts Falcone, who tells the young man that his criminal empire is invincible because it runs on fear. Inspired, Bruce decides to travel the world for several years, learning the various ways of the criminal underworld, before himself becoming a criminal and being arrested. After Bruce's training in the League of Shadows, Ra's and Ducard tell Bruce his purpose: He must lead the League to destroy Gotham, which they believe is corrupt beyond saving. Bruce refuses to become a murderer and battles Ra's, burning the temple in the process, before making his escape. Ra's is killed by falling debris, but Bruce saves an unconscious Ducard and returns to Gotham.

Falcone now dominates the city. Bruce enlists the help of Sgt. [[James Gordon (comics)|Jim Gordon]], one of the city's few honest police officers, and befriends [[Lucius Fox]], a former board member of [[Wayne Enterprises]]. Fox helps Bruce acquire a [[Batmobile|prototype armored car]] and an [[Batsuit|experimental armored suit]]. With Alfred, Bruce finds another entrance to the cave under the well and creates [[Batcave|a workshop]], modifying his equipment to take up the identity of Batman. On his first night out as a vigilante, he intercepts a drug shipment, captures Falcone and provides Rachel with the evidence to [[indictment|indict]] him. Falcone and his men are transferred to [[Arkham Asylum]] with the help of the hospital's corrupt administrator, [[Scarecrow (comics)|Dr. Jonathan Crane]], who has been paying off Falcone to ship a toxic [[hallucinogen]]ic into Gotham City; Crane uses the toxin in his experiments, using his patients as guinea pigs. When Falcone demands a bigger share, Crane gasses Falcone with the same toxin, literally driving him insane with fear. While investigating the drugs, Batman encounters Crane, who also sprays him with the fear toxin. Alfred rescues him, using an anti-toxin developed by Fox. Crane later summons Rachel to Arkham and shows her that the toxin has been introduced into Gotham's water supply from Arkham for weeks, and then infects her. Batman doses Crane with the toxin, saves Rachel, and then takes her to his cave giving her vials for Gordon: One for inoculating himself and the other for mass production.

At Bruce's birthday celebration at [[Wayne Manor]], he is confronted by Ducard, who reveals himself to be the real Ra's al Ghul, and has now arrived in Gotham personally to destroy the city; he had conspired with Crane to poison Gotham's water supply with the toxin, vaporizing it with a stolen device from Wayne Enterprises. After Bruce pretends to be drunk to get everyone to leave, he and Ra's fight. Ra's' men burn down the mansion, release all the inmates at Arkham, and vaporize the hallucinogen into the atmosphere. Although Wayne Manor is destroyed, Bruce escapes the inferno with help from Alfred. Rachel delivers the antidote to Gordon and wards off Crane, now calling himself Scarecrow, with a [[taser]]. Batman reveals his identity to Rachel and then has Gordon drive the Batmobile to Wayne Tower, the central hub of the Gotham elevated rail system. Ra's boards the train; his objective is to reach Wayne Tower with the vaporizer as it is also a major water hub. As Batman confronts Ra's on the train, Gordon destroys the elevated tracks. Batman jams the controls and escapes the train as it crashes, leaving Ra's to die.

Following the battle, Batman becomes a public hero and Bruce gains control of his company; he fires the former CEO, William Earle, and replaces him with Lucius Fox. However, he loses Rachel, who cannot bring herself to love both Bruce and Batman. Gordon, now a Lieutenant, shows Batman the [[Bat-Signal]] and mentions a [[Joker (comics)|new criminal]] who leaves [[Joker (playing card)|Joker playing cards]] at crime scenes. Batman promises to investigate, and disappears into the night.

title: List_of_Nura:_Rise_of_the_Yokai_Clan_episodes
creator: ARCoolguy
added_lines: | ShortSummary = An old ally of the Nura Clan visits to have a discussion about Rikuo's role as future head of the demon clan. Zen has been a long-time supporter of the Nura Clan, a play-mate with Rikuo when he was little; with a weak constitution their family has lent the Nura clan their support in return for protection. Rikuo once again evades the question, explaining he does not wish to become their leader, and Zen leaves doubting the future of the Nura household. As Zen leaves disappointed in his old friend his bodyguard tries to kill him for supporting Rikuo. Just as Zen is about to be killed Rikuo transforms into his other form and kills the traitor.

title: Koprol
creator: Aris riyanto
added_lines:
On May 25, 2010, [[Yahoo!]] announced that it had acquired Koprol for an undisclosed value. Yahoo! had previously considered a US$100 million acquisition of Foursquare, a US-based location-based social network. Yahoo! spokeswoman Rose Tsou stated that "Koprol was uniquely designed for mobile phones and within a year has already built a strong user base" and indicated that Yahoo plans to introduce the service in other markets.<ref name="InformationWeek"/> 
Koprol integrated Yahoo! itself since before the Yahoo! Open Hack Day event in 2009, Koprol became one of Yahoo!'s local partners using multiple technologies such as the Yahoo! API: Yahoo! Fire Eagle, Yahoo! Login, and Yahoo! Contacts.
deleted_lines:

Koprol integrated Yahoo itself since before the Yahoo Open Hack Day event in 2009, Koprol became one of Yahoo's local partners using multiple technologies such as the Yahoo API: Yahoo Fire Eagle, Yahoo Login, and Yahoo Contacts.

title: Farmfoods
added_lines:
'''Farmfoods''' is a [[discounts and allowances|discount]] [[supermarket]] chain in the [[United Kingdom]]. Farmfoods predominately sells [[frozen food]] and also grocery items. 
Farmfoods is a privately-owned business in the [[United Kingdom]]. The brand has been voted one of Scotland's fastest growing businesses.<ref>http://business.scotsman.com/6983/Farmfoods-boss-buys-brothers-21.2589327.jp</ref> 
Farmfoods originated as an [[Aberdeen]]-based meat manufacturing business. Farmfoods then began to freeze products to enable a wider geographical distribution to catering outlets. The firm expanded to dispatched products further afield, to  Scottish cities like [[Glasgow]] and [[Edinburgh]] and with growth, further lines by larger manufacturers such as [[McCain Foods Limited|McCain]] were introduced.
By 1975 the entire business had changed its focus from manufacture distributor/wholesale on frozen food retail. An experimental [[freezer centre]] was set up in Aberdeen. A further 10 freezer centres were opened across Scotland and Farmfoods in its current format was formed.
In the early 1990s, Farmfoods expanded further with the acquisition of the Capital Freezer Centres chain as well as a few smaller freezer centre chains across the country. By 2005, Farmfoods operated more than 300 specialist freezer centres across the UK.
Farmfoods stores are typically located in [[city centre|city and town centres]], usually in stand-alone units, with some stores are located in [[shopping centre]]s. However, recently Farmfoods have started to focus on out-of-town facilities.
The whole of the Farmfoods chain falls into three regions. These being Blairlinn, [[Warrington]] and [[Monkspath]]. In addition to the standard lines offered across the chain, some stores will also offer local produce. 
Generally, stores are in the form of aisles with waist-height freezer cabinets running along each side and shelving above most freezers. 
Recently the company has developed a standard wheelchair-accessible layout for its new stores.
Among other changes made to store entrances this involved the removal of trolly flaps and turn-style entry systems that many stores of this style previously had fitted as a security measure. This move made the stores conform to the relevant disability accessibility regulations.
In 2005 Farmfoods changed the maximum height of shelving in all of its stores. This was a reaction to a number of staff-related accidents relating to staff either falling off cabinets or falling through the glass lids while attempting to stock the higher shelves. Farmfoods' response to thie rate of accidents was to place a poster on all staff noticeboards, highlighting the dangers of standing on freezer lids and stating this practice was strictly forbidden by the business.
Smaller stores tend to have two-four checkouts with space for a customer to place a basket onto the checkout for the cashier to access as they [[Barcode|scan]] each item. The company is currently installing conveyor belt driven checkout areas and upgrading its stores so that all can accept credit and debit cards.
Farmfoods stores typically employ few people. The chain aims to offer products cheaper than [[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland]]. 
The chain also carries one-off special promotions on short-dated, end of line and promotional goods throughout all of its ranges.
Many sections of Farmfoods stores are grouped by the item's price (for example "This Section 25p Each". These price-banded sections are ordinarily 25p, 45p, 59p, 69p, 89p and £1. Products outside of these price brackets, above £1 value are normally rounded to quarters of the pound value.
Although the company continues to focus on providing frozen food, in recent years it has developed a range of  grocery items. There is a mix of branded and in-house brand or own-brand goods. The chain also owns a number of in-house brands.
deleted_lines:
'''Farmfoods''' is a [[discounts and allowances|discount]] [[supermarket]] chain in the [[United Kingdom]]. Farmfoods specialise in [[frozen food]] but also offer an extensive range of everyday essentials and grocery items such as soft drinks, [[toilet paper]], [[confectionery]], bread, milk, desserts, fresh fruit and vegetables. Farmfoods is one of the most successful privately-owned businesses in the [[United Kingdom]] having operated profitably for over 50 years. There are relatively few, successful companies on the high street that remain in private ownership. Farmfoods is one of them; other well-known examples include [[discounts and allowances|discount]] chains [[Wilkinson (retailer)|Wilkinson]], Mackay's, [[B & M|B & M Bargains]] and [[TJ Morris]] (who trade as [[Home Bargains]] in most locations). Farmfoods has also been voted one of Scotland's fastest growing businesses.http://business.scotsman.com/6983/Farmfoods-boss-buys-brothers-21.2589327.jp Farmfoods roots go back to being an [[Aberdeen]]-based meat manufacturing business. Farmfoods then began to freeze products to enable a wider geographical distribution to catering outlets. Steadily, products were dispatched further afield, to major Scottish cities like [[Glasgow]] and [[Edinburgh]] and with growth, further lines by larger manufacturers such as chips by [[McCain Foods Limited|McCain]] were introduced, this, over the chain's development expanded into many of the usual household names known today such as [[Weight Watchers]], [[Tetley Tea]], [[HP Foods]] and [[H. J. Heinz Company|Heinz]] among numerous others. By 1975 the entire business had changed its focus from manufacture distributor/wholesale on frozen food retail. An experimental [[freezer centre]] was set up in Aberdeen and, over a number of years proved very successful. A further 10 freezer centres were opened across Scotland and Farmfoods, in its current format was formed. In the early 1990s, Farmfoods expanded further with the acquisition of the Capital Freezer Centres chain as well as a few smaller freezer centre chains across the country. By 2005, Farmfoods operates more than 300 specialist freezer centres stretching from [[Invergordon]] in the [[North of Scotland]] to Dover in the [[South East of England]]. Farmfoods stores are typically located in [[city centre|city and town centres]], more-often-than-not in stand-alone units with their own free car parking, however occasionally stores are located in [[shopping centre]]s. However, recently Farmfoods have started to focus on opening stores near the edge of towns, where they have their own larger car parks and are able to open for longer periods. == Store re-branding 2009 == The entire chain underwent a complete rebranding exercise during the first two quarters of 2009. These are now nearing their completion in the southern regions and have been completed in Scottish areas as well as the [[North of England]]. The chain is relaunching to be less of a "hardcore discounter" to more of a [[middle class]] "great value" brand. With this, the varying shades of blue in stores, and bags resembling those of 1970s [[Tesco]] carriers are gone. These are all to be replaced by blacks and greens. The Farmfoods logo itself is now re-enforced by a sunny farm scene which can be seen in all stores on everything from shopfront signs and car park signs to freezers, uniforms and bags (the latter two are being rolled out) As of 2009 the company's slogan has changed from "Where Customers Count", which was used for a number of years, to a combination of two "Freezing in the Goodness" and "Great Food at Amazing Prices". These new slogans are also strongly re-enforced in the chains re-branded stores, leaflets, bags and television adverts. The current opening hours for all stores classed as town centre stores are:
Mon 8:00-20:00
Tue 8:00-20:00
Wed 8:00-20:00
Thu 8:00-20:00
Fri 8:00-20:00
Sat 8:00-18:00
Sun 9:00-18:00 (10:00-16:00 in some stores) The current opening hours for all stores classed as out of town stores are:
Mon 8:00-22:00
Tue 8:00-22:00
Wed 8:00-22:00
Thu 8:00-22:00
Fri 8:00-22:00
Sat 8:00-18:00 (8:00-20:00 in some stores)
Sun 9:00-18:00 (10:00-16:00 in some stores) The whole of the Farmfoods chain falls into three "regions". These being Blairlinn, [[Warrington]] and [[Monkspath]]. Depending on the trading focus in each of these areas store positioning, in-store layouts and focus lines (blockier items in-store) tend to vary slightly based on the preferential regional tastes of the geographical area. For example, stores in [[Staffordshire]] stock the locally produced oatcakes where stores outside of this area wouldn't and may stock their own locality's specialities. Generally, stores are in the form of aisles with waist-height freezer cabinets running along each side and shelving above most freezers. Popular items, such as soft drinks and canned foods are often stack in the middle on aisles but is now in the middle of a refit to stop middle aisle stacks and have items on the shelves to make more room for customers. There are many exceptions to this generalisation as all stores are unique. Some stores have sections with full height shelving. These full height shelving units more-often-than-not house groups of products such as pet foods or toilet paper and other household items. Across the design of each shop had been tailored to the general layout of the store. Since many of the older stores were not built to be freezer centres they are often too small and awkwardly shaped making them hard to traverse. Recently the company has developed a standard wheelchair friendly layout which all the new and much larger stores, such as [[Cumbernauld]], [[Cambuslang]], Sutton and [[Coatbridge]] all conform to. Older stores were in 2005 adapted and had their previous layouts altered to make movement around the stores easier and more pleasant. Among other changes made to store entrances this involved the removal of trolly flaps and turn-style entry systems that many stores of this style previously had fitted as a security measure. Not only did this move make the stores conform to the relevant disability accessibility regulations but they also made the stores more open and welcoming it also allowed the free-flowing movement of trolleys from the shop itself to vehicles located in the car park. In 2005 Farmfoods changed the maximum height of shelving in all of its stores. This was a reaction to a number of staff-related accidents relating to staff either falling off cabinets or falling through the glass lids while attempting to stock the higher shelves. This time a poster was placed on all staff notice boards highlighting the dangers of standing on freezer lids and stating this practice was strictly forbidden by the business. Smaller stores tend to have two-four checkouts with space for a customer to place a basket onto the checkout for the cashier to access as they [[Barcode|scan]] each item. The company is currently installing conveyor belt driven checkout areas, improved scanning and card acceptance facilities across all stores. The new conveyor belt systems provide considerably more space to place scanned items and allow the checkout experience to be more streamlined for customers with trolleys as they are not required to lift shopping to the checkout as they are served. Improved scanning facilities allow for a faster checkout experience and faster, fixed credit/[[debit card]] acceptance facilities will shortly be rolled out across all stores. All new stores opened by the company as of autumn 2007 have these new checkout facilities. Farmfoods stores are typically between 6000-9000 Sq. ft http://www.farmfoods.co.uk/index.php?p=property Farmfoods stores typically employ few people. The chain aims to offer products cheaper than [[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland]]. Recently the business has been looking to alter its trading stance slightly; previously trading in some goods running a little close to their best before dates (BBEs), however with most supermarket chains now maintaining their profit margins using this method (as a means to purchase goods from suppliers at a lower price) farmfoods are now also looking to move out of the league of "hardcore" discounter, such as [[Netto (store)|Netto]], to up its game and reposition itself as a "great value" food and essentials retailer - where the perception by customers is one of "good value and good products" rather than "cheap and nasty" The chain will also continue to carry one-off special promotions on short-dated, end of line and promotional goods throughout all of its ranges. All items are individually priced, and many have a multi-buy price (for example, 29p or 5 for £1) and other such offers like ''"buy one, get one free"'' (BOGOF). Many sections of Farmfoods stores are grouped by the item's price (for example "This Section 25p Each" - a policy which is proven to be a popular one but at the same time ever disappearing from the British high street. These price-banded sections are ordinarily 25p, 45p, 59p, 69p, 89p and £1. Products outside of these price brackets, above £1 value are normally rounded to quarters of the pound value - EG: £1.25, £1.50, £1.75, £2.00, £2.25 etc... Although the company continues to focus on providing frozen food, in recent years it has developed a large range of complementary grocery items. There is a mix of branded and in-house brand or own-brand goods. A few of the brands stocked are [[H. J. Heinz Company|Heinz]], [[Weight Watchers]], [[McCain Foods Limited|McCain]], [[HP Foods]] and [[Princes (company)|Princes]] among others. The chain also owned a number of in-house brand names, exclusive to Farmfoods stores, along with their own brand lines. Their in-house brands include Finest Catch, Easy Cook, Super Savers, LA Diner, Betty Smith's, Harry Smith's. A number of which are produced by [http://www.kingparrotfoods.com King Parrot Foods]

title: Chicken_Run
creator: Ap
added_lines: But the next day, Ginger finds Rocky has fled, leaving behind a segment of a poster that reveals he was part of a circus act, and able to "fly" only when launched out of a cannon. Ginger and the other chickens lose hope of escape.  A huge brawl in the mud ensues, until Ginger discovers that Fowler, the farm's aged (and blustery) rooster, was once an honorary member of the [[Royal Air Force]]. With Fowler's knowledge, and with the nervous and nerdy Mac's [[aeronautical engineering]], the chickens  work feverishly to design and build a [[flying machine]] in secret from Mr. Tweedy, who has become suspect of the chickens' ingenuity. The machine would be [[Human powered aircraft|pedal-powered]] by the chickens themselves. The craft is completed just as the repairs on the pie-making machine are finished. Mr. Tweedy tries to grab the chickens and start the production of pies, but they swarm him and pin him under one of the coops.
deleted_lines: But the next day, Ginger finds Rocky has fled, leaving behind a part of a poster that explains that he was part of a circus act, only "flying" over the land after being launched out of a cannon. Ginger and the other chickens lose hope of escape.  A huge brawl in the mud ensues, until Ginger finds out that Fowler, the farm's aged rooster, was once an honorary member of the [[Royal Air Force]]. With Fowler's knowledge, and with the nervous and nerdy Mac's [[aeronautical engineering]], the chickens  work feverishly to design and build a [[flying machine]] in secret from Mr. Tweedy, who has become suspect of the chickens' ingenuity. The machine would be [[Human powered aircraft|pedal-powered]] by the chickens themselves. The craft is completed just as the repairs on the pie-making machine are finished. Mr. Tweedy tries to grab the chickens and start the production of pies, but they swarm him and pin him under one of the coops.

title: Amiga_demos
creator: Shd~enwiki
added_lines:
A "demo" is a demonstration of the multimedia capabilities of a computer (or more to the point, a demonstration of the skill of the demo's constructors). There was intense rivalry during the 1990s among the best programmers, graphic artists and computer musicians to continually outdo each other's demos. Since the Amiga's hardware was more or less fixed (unlike today's PC industry, where arbitrary combinations of hardware can be put together), there was competition http://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Special:LandingCheck?landing_page=WMFJA1&language=en&country=CA&utm_source=2010_JA1_Banner2_button_EN1&utm_medium=sitenotice&utm_campaign=20101119JA02to test the limits of that hardware and perform theoretically "impossible" feats by re-factoring the problem at hand. The Amiga was the undisputed leader of mainstream multimedia computing in the late 1980s and early 1990s, though it was inevitably overtaken by PC architecture.
The demo scene spearheaded development in multimedia programming techniques for the Amiga, such that it was [[de rigueur]] for the latest visual tricks, sound trackers and 3D algorithms from the demo scene to end up being used in computer game development.
Eric Schwartz produced a series of animated demos that ran with [[Movie Player]], an animation software package similar to [[Macromedia Flash]]. The animated demos drew heavily on the whimsy and graphic style of comic strips.
[[Red Sector Incorporated]] (RSI) produced a piece of software called the RSI Demo maker, which allowed users to script their own demos, replete with scroll text, vector balls, plasma screens, etc.

Since the Amiga's hardware was more or less fixed (unlike today's PC industry, where arbitrary combinations of hardware can be put together), there was competition http://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Special:LandingCheck?landing_page=WMFJA1&language=en&country=CA&utm_source=2010_JA1_Banner2_button_EN1&utm_medium=sitenotice&utm_campaign=20101119JA02to test the limits of that hardware and perform theoretically "impossible" feats by refactoring the problem at hand. [[Red Sector Incorporated]] (RSI) produced a piece of software called the RSI Demomaker, which allowed users to script their own demos, replete with scrolltext, vectorballs, plasma screens, etc.

title: Jana_Gana_Mana
added_lines: The original poem written by Rabinder Nath Tagore was translated into Hindi by Abid Ali. The original hindi version of the song Jana Gana Mana, translated by Ali and based on the poem by Tagore, was a little different. It was "Sukh Chain Ki Barkha Barase, Bharat Bhagya Hai Jaga....". The present National Anthem was composed by Capt Ram Singh as Qaumi Tarana of the INA at Singapore in 1943. ''Jana Gana Mana'' was officially adopted by the Constituent Assembly as the Indian national anthem on January 24, 1950.<ref name="patent">[http://india.gov.in/knowindia/national_anthem.php National Anthem - Know India. Nation Portal of India. Government of India.]</ref><ref name=bhatt>{{cite book

'''IBM  WebSphere Application Server''' ('''WAS'''), a software [[application server]], is the flagship product within [[IBM]]'s [[IBM WebSphere|WebSphere]] brand. WAS is built using [[open standard]]s such as [[Java Platform, Enterprise Edition|Java EE]], [[XML]], and [[Web service|Web Services]]. It is supported on the following platforms: Windows, AIX, Linux, Solaris, HP-UX, IBM i and [[WebSphere Application Server for z/OS | z/OS]].  Beginning with Version 6.1 and now into Version 7, the open standard specifications are aligned and common across all the platforms.  Platform exploitation, to the extent it takes place, is done ''below'' the open standard specification line.

title: The_Origin_(novel)
creator: Sweetmoose6
added_lines:
'''''The Origin''''' is a [[biographical novel]] of the life of [[Charles Darwin]] written by [[Irving Stone]].  Darwin was a geologist and could be considered the father of [[evolutionary]] theory.  The novel begins with Darwin at the age of 22 (Stone 1980, p. 3) and follows him through the [[Voyage of the Beagle]] until his death in 1882 (p. 760). Stone took five years to research and write the novel (n.p. acknowledgements) and consulted numerous Darwin scholars and even Darwin's descendants in order to write his version of Darwin's life (pp. 763-764).
Stone, I (1980) "The Origin", Doubleday.
deleted_lines:
'''''The Origin''''' is a [[biographical novel]] of the life of [[Charles Darwin]] written by [[Irving Stone]].  Darwin was an anthropologist and could be considered the father of [[evolutionary]] theory.  The novel begins with Darwin at the age of 22 and follows him through the [[Voyage of the Beagle]] until his death in 1882.

Stone took five years to research and write the novel and consulted numerous Darwin scholars and even Darwin's descendants in order to write his version of Darwin's life.
*[[Stephen Jay Gould]]. [http://books.google.com/books?id=rfuDnYKBA7MC&pg=PA449&dq=Irving-Stone+%22The+Origin%22+Darwin&lr=&as_brr=3&ei=-NHNSPfTHZrqiQH_osSJDA&sig=ACfU3U3p-M98XCUYn36dPcrJfWjOuG0thQ#PPA449,M1 ''On Telling, Altering and Enriching Stories: An Unpublished Darwin Letter from a Key Incident in his Later Life.''] Evolutionary Paleobiology (David Jablonski, Douglas H. Erwin and Jere H. Lipps, editors),  pp. 437–460; University of Chicago Press, 1996. ISBN 9780226389110.

title: Danger_Days:_The_True_Lives_of_the_Fabulous_Killjoys
creator: Kezza1256
added_lines: The final track, "Vampire Money", has a bastardised version of the band singing an ode to selling out ("play the game and take the band real far"). This was a reaction to the band being asked to do a song for the film ''[[The Twilight Saga: New Moon|New Moon]]'', part of the ''[[The Twilight Saga (film series)|Twilight]]'' franchise. Gerard Way said that the reason the song was on the album was because "there’s a lot of people chasing that fucking money. ‘Twilight?’ A lot of people around us were like, ‘please, for the love of God, do this fucking movie.’ But we’d moved on." Additionally, the opening of "Vampire Money" is a parody of Sweet's cover of "Ballroom Blitz," which begins "Are you ready Steeve?" ("Uh huh.") "Andy?" ("Yea.") "Mick?" ("Okay.") "Alright fells, let's go!" Gerard Way affects a British accent and mimics, "Well, are you ready, Ray?" ("Yea.") "How about you Frank? ("All night, baby.") "How about you, Mikey?" (Fuckin' ready.") "Well, I think I'm alright."
deleted_lines: The final track, "Vampire Money", has a bastardised version of the band singing an ode to selling out ("play the game and take the band real far"). This was a reaction to the band being asked to do a song for the film ''[[The Twilight Saga: New Moon|New Moon]]'', part of the ''[[The Twilight Saga (film series)|Twilight]]'' franchise. Gerard Way said that the reason the song was on the album was because "there’s a lot of people chasing that fucking money. ‘Twilight?’ A lot of people around us were like, ‘please, for the love of God, do this fucking movie.’ But we’d moved on."

comment: Removed all incorrect claims and stuff that was just copied from the Houdini web page
title: Houdini_(chess)
creator: Drmrboss
added_lines:
Houdini (free for non-commercial use) is a state-of-the-art chess engine for Windows, by Robert Houdart. According to the author "The name Houdini was chosen because of the engine's positional style, its tenacity in difficult positions and its ability to defend stubbornly and escape with a draw – sometimes by the narrowest of margins. On the other hand Houdini will often use razor-sharp tactics to deny its opponents escape routes when it has the better position".
Houdini 1.5 is widely regarded as the strongest chess engine currently available. As of December 17, 2010, Houdini 1.5 was ranked #1 on the leading IPON computer chess rating list, 50 Elo ahead of Rybka 4 and 100 Elo ahead of Stockfish 1.9 and Critter 0.9.
 http://www.inwoba.de/
deleted_lines:
Houdini (free for non-commercial use) is a state-of-the-art chess engine for Windows, by Robert Houdart. According to the author "The name Houdini was chosen because of the engine's positional style, its tenacity in difficult positions and its ability to defend stubbornly and escape with a draw – sometimes by the narrowest of margins. On the other hand Houdini will often use razor-sharp tactics to deny its opponents escape routes when it has the better position". As of December 17, 2010, Houdini 1.5 was ranked #1 on the leading IPON computer chess rating list, 50 Elo ahead of Rybka 4 and 100 Elo ahead of Stockfish 1.9 and Critter 0.9. Actually Houdini is an unofficial current blitz champion agreed by all computer chess engine testing websites and amateur testers, at least 50 Elo better than her rivals, however there are still very few testers for long time control and is still controversial in there.
The style of Houdini is aggressive and dynamic, where the default contempt value by author is 1 (0 is neutral and 2 is very aggressive). Houdini sometimes sacrifices pawns for the compensation in development and mobility of pieces, which is unique feature of Houdini.  Houdini can be regarded as a modified engine of Robolito, Ivanhoe and IPPOLIT family (assumption of most chess testers and also admit by the author). According to the author, the engine has several multiples of lines of codes than that of original family engines. The node count speed and evaluation are somewhat similar to that of  IPPOLIT family engines which have several times better in speed and depth evaluation performance than Rybka 4( The most successful  commercial engine in current computer chess tournaments).
Version history
Houdini 1.5

    * Houdini 1.50 (20101215): Improved search and evaluation. Gaviota Table Base Support.

Houdini 1.0

    * Houdini 1.03a (20100717): Bug fix for Multi-PV.
    * Houdini 1.03 (20100715): Multi-PV, searchmove and large page support. Improved evaluation function.
    * Houdini 1.02 (20100618): SMP and hash collision bug fixes. Work-around for Shredder GUI.
    * Houdini 1.01 (20100601): Bug fixes. Improved search algorithm.
    * Houdini 1.00 (20100515): First release.
 http://www.inwoba.de/
 http://www.chesslogik.com/
 http://ippolit.wikispaces.com/History
 http://ahmed-chess.forumotion.com/portal

*Stewardess: Welcome to Inversion Layer Airlines, sir. In what section are you traveling?
*Jon (whispering): Third class.

*Jon (whispering): Third class.
*Stewardess: I can't hear you!

title: Cessna_177_Cardinal
creator: Ericg
deleted_lines:
==Accidents and incidents==
*On 11 April 1996, a Cessna 177B carrying 7-year-old [[Jessica Dubroff]], her [[certified flight instructor]] and her father, crashed after take-off from [[Cheyenne Airport]] in [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]], killing all on board. Dubroff was attempting to set a cross-country record for young pilots, although her instructor was thought to have been at the controls at the time of the accident. No defect in the aircraft itself was found. The accident resulted in general public concern and new Federal legislation banning record attempts by non-holders of private pilot or higher certificates.<ref name="Avweb7Jul97"> {{cite web|url = http://www.avweb.com/news/safety/183036-1.html|title = The Jessica Dubroff Accident |accessdate = 2009-08-18|last = AvWeb|authorlink = |year = 2009|month = August}}</ref><ref name="FindLaw"> {{cite web|url = http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/casecode/uscodes/49/subtitles/vii/parts/a/subparts/iii/chapters/447/sections/section_44724.html|title =TITLE 49 - TRANSPORTATION, SUBTITLE VII - AVIATION PROGRAMS, PART A - AIR COMMERCE AND SAFETY, SUBPART III - SAFETY,  CHAPTER 447 - SAFETY REGULATION |accessdate = 2009-08-18|last = United States Code|authorlink = |year = 2004|month = January}}</ref>

title: Earache_My_Eye
creator: Skunk Stuffy
added_lines: The song was also released as a single in 1974, and reached #9 on the Billboard charts and #4 in [[Canada]].  In [[Chicago]], it topped the charts at the powerful and influential [[Contemporary hit radio|Top 40 radio]] station [[WLS (AM)]], holding the #1 position for one week in September 1974, in the middle of an eleven week run on the station's [[top 40]] airplay charts. The B-side, "Turn That Thing Down" features the remainder of the musical track, from the point of Marin's [[monologue]] about his wealth, without the actual dialogue, complete to its conclusion.  It is possible to assemble the full-length version of the song by editing the two sections together.  The version featured on ''[[Cheech & Chong's Greatest Hit]]'' fades out before reaching the skit as it appears on the single and the ''Wedding Album'' LP.
deleted_lines: The song was also released as a single in 1974, and reached #9 on the Billboard charts and #4 in [[Canada]].  In [[Chicago]], it topped the charts at the powerful and influential [[Contemporary hit radio|Top 40 radio]] station [[WLS (AM)]], holding the #1 position for one week in September 1974, in the middle of an eleven week run on the station's [[top 40]] airplay charts. The B-side, "Turn That Thing Down" (a non-[[LP album|LP]] track) features the remainder of the musical track, from the point of Marin's [[monologue]] about his wealth, without the actual dialogue, complete to its conclusion.  It is possible to assemble the full-length version of the song by editing the two sections together.  The version featured on ''[[Cheech & Chong's Greatest Hit]]'' fades out before reaching the skit as it appears on the single and the ''Wedding Album'' LP.

title: Cookie_exchange
creator: Grimesjdg
added_lines:
The '''cookie exchange''' in [[IPsec]] comes under the [[Oakley protocol]], which is a protocol of key management. The cookie exchange requires that each side send a [[pseudorandom ]]number, the cookie, in the initial message, which the other side acknowledges. This acknowledgement must be repeated in the first message of the [[Diffie-Hellman key exchange]]. If the source address was forged, the opponent gets no answer. Thus, an opponent can only force a user to generate acknowledgements and not to perform the Diffie-Hellman calculation. Note that "cookies" in the sense of IPsec are unrelated to HTTP cookies used by web browsers.
[[Category:Internet protocols]]
<!-- Don't put this in category HTTP. This article talks about cookies in the sense of the IPsec protocol. That has nothing to do with HTTP cookies. -->
deleted_lines:

This acknowledgement must be repeated in the first message of the [[Diffie-Hellman key exchange]]. If the source address was forged, the opponent gets no answer. title: Bugs_Bunny
creator: Qbmessiah
added_lines:
ต===Bugs Bunny emerges===
''on July 27, 1920, is the first cartoon where both Elmer Fud and Bugs are shown in their fully developed forms as hunter and destingush.  In this cartoon Mel Blank first uses what would become the standard voice of Bugs. And Bugs first emerges from his rabbit habitat to ask Elmer, "What's up,mr. Doc?" how you are doing
deleted_lines:
===Bugs Bunny emerges===
''[[A Wild Hare]]'', directed by Tex Avery and released on July 27, 1940, is the first cartoon where both Elmer Fudd and Bugs are shown in their fully developed forms as hunter and tormentor.  In this cartoon Mel Blanc first uses what would become the standard voice of Bugs. And Bugs first emerges from his rabbit hole to ask Elmer, "What's up, Doc?"  Animation historian Joe Adamson counts ''A Wild Hare'' as the first "official" Bugs Bunny short.<ref name="Adamson">{{Cite book|title=Bugs Bunny: 50 Years and Only One Grey Hare|first=Joe|last=Adamson|year=1990|publisher=Henry Holt|isbn=0-8050-1855-7}}</ref>   

Bugs's second appearance in Jones's ''[[Elmer's Pet Rabbit]]'' introduces the audience to the name Bugs Bunny, which until then had only been used among the Termite Terrace employees. It was also the first short where he received billing under his now-famous name, but the card, "featuring Bugs Bunny", was just slapped on the end of the completed short's opening titles when ''A Wild Hare'' proved an unexpected success. The rabbit here is in look and voice identical to the one in Jones' earlier ''Elmer's Candid Camera''. 

Bugs in his ''Wild Hare'' likeness appeared in five more shorts during 1941. ''[[Tortoise Beats Hare]]'', directed by Tex Avery, features the first appearance of [[Cecil Turtle]]; ''[[Hiawatha's Rabbit Hunt]]'', is the first Bugs Bunny short directed by [[Friz Freleng]]; ''[[All This and Rabbit Stew]]'', directed by Avery, has Bugs tracked by a little African-American hunter (based heavily on racial stereotypes); ''[[The Heckling Hare]]'' was the final Bugs short Avery worked on before being fired (Avery and producer Schlesinger vehemently disagreed over the ending gag of The Heckling Hare, and Avery refused to compromise his creative principles) and leaving for [[MGM]]; and ''[[Wabbit Twouble]]'', the first Bugs short directed by [[Robert Clampett]]. ''Wabbit Twouble'' was also the first of five Bugs shorts to feature a chubbier remodel of Elmer Fudd, a short-lived attempt to have Fudd more closely resemble his voice actor, comedian [[Arthur Q. Bryan]].
